subject: Re: Junit-add-ons to test private methods.

messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Ty Paywa <tyronepaywa@y...> wrote:
> If you need to test private methods then they should
> not be private. In my testing I have not found any
> real good excuse to test a private method.
>
> Ty

Hmm. I primarily use public/package-level(default)/private access to
communicate which other classes should be calling this method. (And
protected is a whole different ball of wax.) If you're doing open- or
black-box testing, then this works pretty well for providing the right
level of access to your test methods. (Well, even that's not true.
You can lay out your package structure to work well with
package-level/private distinctions, or public/private distinctions,
but not both.)

I encounter situations, particularly ones that have heavy
algorithmics, where the class only exposes certain methods, but one or
more of those methods could benefit from being decomposed for testing
purposes. Usually, there is decomposition of the algorithm in the
production class. Sometimes, I simply expose what might be thought of
as private details. Sometimes, I can think of a better way to
structure the problem, and am not worried about exposing the
internals. But sometimes, I really don't want to expose the internals
to other production classes, but still want to be able to get at those
points for testing.

Eric
